thread.title: Could 2021 be the International Year of Rangelands and Pastoralists
thread.title_full: Could 2021 be the International Year of Rangelands and Pastoralists

title: Could 2021 be the International Year of Rangelands and Pastoralists
text:
By Lydia Burton Updated November 02, 2016 16:03:00 Map: Longreach 4730 
Australia is jumping behind a global bid to lobby the United Nations for 2021 to be the International Year of Rangelands and Pastoralists. 
Delegates from more than 50 countries unanimously agreed at this year's International Rangelands conference in Canada, to push for a year to recognise the outback and its people. 
Australian Rangeland Society President David Phelps said the passionate people who live and work on the rangelands deserve to be recognised. 
"About 70 to 80 per cent of Australia's land mass is rangelands," he said. 
"Globally more than half of [the earth's] lands are rangelands. 
"It's the drier lands, everything from deserts to sub-tropical savannahs. 
"While there is a whole range of land uses [in the rangelands], pastoralism is the one that we are most keen to highlight, because it is just so important to people's livelihoods right around the world. 
"It's almost like global year of the outback." 
Mr Phelps said recognition through an international year would connect graziers throughout the world. 
"Here in Australia pastoralism is our graziers, basically," he said. 
"In Africa and Mongolia it is still herders, so it [an international year] is also a way for us to link that international community of pastoralists. 
"It is really a push to have all of those passionate people who look after livestock right around the world and who are passionate about their rangeland landscapes, to give them recognition. Photo: The rangelands are the drier regions in the world and make up more than half of the earths land mass. (ABC Rural: Lydia Burton) 
But, Mr Phelps said an International Year of Rangelands and Pastoralists would also help first world countries share knowledge and resources with developing nations. 
"It is really important for developing nations to have a spotlight on them to have a greater focus from the United Nations, Food and Agriculture Organisation and the The World Bank," he said. 
"It does focus the efforts of the UN into developing nations and it does actually provide extra funding, so that is really important in that respect. 
"It can also help us [Australia] focus our overseas aid efforts and focus our expertise. 
"There are so many Australians being innovative in rangeland environments that this could give us that extra push to help some of the developing nations. 
"But it can also help shine the spotlight on our own rangelands and pastoralists, on outback Australia and our graziers and it can help shine the spotlight on us for tourism. 
"Also I guess shine the spotlight on the outback for the innovation and the contribution we can make to the international community." 
Mr Phelps said he believed there was an excellent chance of the International Year of Rangelands and Pastoralists going ahead, but said it was just a matter of when. 
"We are all so confident it is such a great idea and so important to Australia that the Australian Government, our State and Territory Governments and local governments will all get in behind the cause as well and basically say to the UN 'Hey, this is a great idea. Let's do it'," he said.
